resources.string:
Welcome to SenSE - a joint project by the Julius and Rensselaer High Frequency Integrated Circuits (RHFIC) Labs at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.


 We are working toward an optimized life experience.


 The app is in the first stages of analyzing your circadian rhythm, which will eventually allow us build an ecosystem targeted at increasing overall wakefulness and cognitive alertness.


To do this, we analyze your heart rate from Fitbit and extract the circadian component. More information is available on the Visualization page

The circadian rhythm plays a vital role in our overall well-being. From our sleep patterns and alertness, to our body temperature and metabolism, our circadian rhythm can have huge effects on how we feel.\n\n Because of this, it\'s important that we can measure the rhythm and identify when issues arise. The SenSE app implements a filtering algorithm that tries to do this using your heart rate data.

SenSE is an ongoing project with contributors from the Julius and Rensselaer High Frequency Integrated Circuits (RHFIC) Labs at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.\n\n We\'re a group of researchers focused on improving our understanding of circadian dynamics with the hope of doing some good with that knowledge.
The app requests your heart rate data from Fitbit and processes it on your phone. Everything is kept encrypted on your phone, and we never have access to your data.
Why is your circadian health important?

The graph above shows your raw heart rate from Fitbit overlayed with the filtered output which we take to be your circadian rhythm.

 We get this output by isolating harmonics from the heart rate, which allow us estimate how your rhythm progresses over the day.

 The algorithm is based on the Observer-Based Filter that was developed by the Julius Lab. By combining linear control theory with gradient-free optimization, we're able to tune the filter to fit your data.

 We hope that as our research progresses, we will be able to combine these measurements with control algorithms that can help optimize your circadian dynamics - getting light at the right times, sleeping at the right times, etc.

The app has not been authorized yet, so we cannot visualize your data. Please navigate to settings to log in to Fitbit.\n\n Once you\'re logged in, the app will request your heart rate data from Fitbit and run it through the Observer-Based Filtering algorithm developed by the Julius Lab.
